An attractant stimulus, whether chemical or thermal, causes elevated methylation of the receptors, which shuts off the attractant signal output. In contrast, a repellent stimulus brings about lowered levels of methylation to counteract the repellent signal (15Kehry M.R. Dahlquist F.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10378-10386Google Scholar). Increases and decreases in methylation levels correspond to the magnitudes of attractant and repellent stimuli, respectively. It should be noted that some of the methyl-accepting glutamate residues are derived from glutamine residues in the primary translational products (19Kehry M.R. Bond M.W. Hunkapiller M.W. Dahlquist F.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 3599-3603Google Scholar, 20Sherris D. Parkinson J.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 6051-6055Google Scholar). CheB is also responsible for the specific and irreversible deamidation of these groups.Extensive genetic and biochemical studies on bacterial chemotaxis have identified all of the protein components involved in the chemotactic signal transduction pathway from the detection of attractants and repellents to the control of swimming behavior (for review, see 10Bourret R.B. Borkovich K.A. Simon M.I. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 401-441Google Scholar, 11Stock J.B. Lukat G.S. Stock A.M. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biophys. Chem. 1991; 20: 109-136Google Scholar, 12Manson M.D. Adv. Microb. Physiol. 1992; 33: 277-346Google Scholar, 13Parkinson J.S. Cell. 1993; 73: 857-871Google Scholar). In brief, when a chemoreceptor binds to a repellent, it activates the cytoplasmic autophosphorylating protein kinase CheA that can transfer phosphate group to the cytoplasmic signaling protein CheY and the receptor methylesterase CheB. Phospho-CheY interacts with switch component(s) of the flagellar motor to cause its clockwise rotation; phospho-CheB demethylates chemoreceptor molecules to shut off the tumbling signal. On the other hand, binding of an attractant to a receptor causes inhibition of CheA kinase, which results in a decrease in CheY and CheB phosphorylation. The same signaling pathway (from the receptor to the flagellar motor) is utilized in thermotaxis, but the mechanism underlying thermosensing has not been elucidated.Each receptor forms a ternary complex with CheA and the coupling protein CheW (21Gegner J.A. Graham D.R. Roth A.F. Dahlquist F.W. Cell. 1992; 70: 975-982Google Scholar). Since the complex is stable in vitro (21Gegner J.A. Graham D.R. Roth A.F. Dahlquist F.W. Cell. 1992; 70: 975-982Google Scholar, 22Schuster S.C. Swanson R.V. Alex L.A. Bourret R.B. Simon M.I. Nature. 1993; 365: 343-347Google Scholar) and in vivo (23Maddock J. Shapiro L. Science. 1993; 259: 1717-1723Google Scholar), receptor-mediated control of CheA activity is thought to occur through structural changes within this receptor-CheW-CheA complex. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the thermosensing mechanism involves similar structural changes in the ternary complex to those caused by increases and decreases in temperature. It should be stressed that temperature dependence of autophosphorylation, phosphotransfer, or dephosphorylation cannot simply explain thermotaxis. Rather, the receptors seem to be primary thermosensors (2Maeda K. Imae Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 91-95Google Scholar, 3Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 360-367Google Scholar, 4Lee L. Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1988; 170: 4769-4774Google Scholar, 5Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 377-382Google Scholar, 6Nara T. Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 1120-1124Google Scholar): they fall into two classes, namely warm receptors (Tsr, Tar, and Trg) and cold receptors (Tar in the presence of attractants (see below) and Tap). A warm receptor produces attractant and repellent signals upon increases and decreases in temperature, respectively, whereas a cold receptor mediates the opposite responses to the same stimuli (6Nara T. Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 1120-1124Google Scholar).Interestingly, two lines of evidence suggest that covalent modification of the methyl-accepting sites might influence the thermosensing properties of the receptors. First, cheB-defective strains, which can respond to but cannot adapt to chemotactic stimuli, show no thermoresponse, whereas cheR-defective strains, which cannot adapt either, retain thermosensing abilities (2Maeda K. Imae Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 91-95Google Scholar, 24Imae Y. Mizuno T. Maeda K. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 368-374Google Scholar). The absence of a thermoresponse in cheB mutants might be due to the absence of deamidation and/or demethylation of the receptors. Alternatively, CheB might be involved in the thermosensing/signaling process: e.g. it might constitute a thermosensor complex with the receptor, CheW and CheA. Second, Tar produces inverted thermotactic signals in the presence of any of its specific attractants, such as aspartate and maltose (3Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 360-367Google Scholar, 5Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 377-382Google Scholar). Whereas it usually functions as a warm receptor, Tar appears to be converted into a cold receptor after adapting to an attractant. Enhanced methylation of Tar has been proposed to cause this attractant-dependent conversion of thermoreceptor function.In this study, we have studied the roles of the methyl-accepting residues (Gln295, Glu302, Gln309, and Glu491: the set of the four residues will be referred to as [QEQE] throughout this paper) in the thermosensing function of Tar, by examining thermosensing profiles in the various genetic background.DISCUSSIONIn this study, we have demonstrated that the primary translational product of tar (Tar with [QEQE]) does not have thermosensing ability (Fig. 1), but acquires it by the deamidation of either Gln295 or Gln309 (Table I). The multifunctional nature of bacterial chemoreceptors has been exploited to isolate mutants defective only in the response for a specific chemoeffector, leading to the identification of the amino acid residues responsible for its recognition (for Tar and Tsr, see 5Lee L. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 6340-6348Google Scholar).We have also shown that the unmethylated ([EEEE]) and the heavily methylated ([EmEmEmEm]) forms of Tar function as a warm receptor and a cold receptor, respectively. The unmethylated form of Tar mediated a normal thermoresponse in the presence of glycerol (Fig. 2). However, under no conditions tested, did it show any characteristics of a cold receptor in the cheB cheR background. In contrast, the heavily methylated form (i.e. the genetically deamidated Tar expressed in the cheB background) mediated an inverted thermoresponse in the presence of aspartate (Fig. 4). Under no conditions tested did it show any characteristics of a warm receptor. Thus, the specific methylation, and possibly the presence of aspartate or any of the other Tar-mediated attractants also, are required for the conversion of Tar from a warm to a cold receptor.In summary, covalent modification of the four methyl-accepting residues of Tar modulates thermosensing properties of the receptor. These findings reinforce the notion that thermotaxis is resulted from a temperature-dependent shift in an equilibrium between the two signaling states (corresponding to smooth swimming and tumbling) of the receptor itself. Further investigation of the effects of covalent modification would provide an important clue to elucidate what kind of structural change of the receptor plays an essential role in thermosensing. Dahlquist F.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10378-10386Google Scholar, 16Terwilliger T.C. Koshland Jr., D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 7719-7725Google Scholar). Methylation and demethylation are the basis of adaptation in chemo/thermotaxis and are catalyzed by CheR and CheB, respectively (17Springer W.R. Koshland Jr., D.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 533-537Google Scholar, 18Stock J.B. Koshland Jr., D.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1978; 75: 3659-3663Google Scholar). An attractant stimulus, whether chemical or thermal, causes elevated methylation of the receptors, which shuts off the attractant signal output. In contrast, a repellent stimulus brings about lowered levels of methylation to counteract the repellent signal (15Kehry M.R. Dahlquist F.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10378-10386Google Scholar). Increases and decreases in methylation levels correspond to the magnitudes of attractant and repellent stimuli, respectively. It should be noted that some of the methyl-accepting glutamate residues are derived from glutamine residues in the primary translational products (19Kehry M.R. Bond M.W. Hunkapiller M.W. Dahlquist F.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 3599-3603Google Scholar, 20Sherris D. Parkinson J.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 6051-6055Google Scholar). CheB is also responsible for the specific and irreversible deamidation of these groups.Extensive genetic and biochemical studies on bacterial chemotaxis have identified all of the protein components involved in the chemotactic signal transduction pathway from the detection of attractants and repellents to the control of swimming behavior (for review, see 10Bourret R.B. Borkovich K.A. Simon M.I. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 401-441Google Scholar, 11Stock J.B. Lukat G.S. Stock A.M. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biophys. Chem. 1991; 20: 109-136Google Scholar, 12Manson M.D. Adv. Microb. Physiol. 1992; 33: 277-346Google Scholar, 13Parkinson J.S. Cell. 1993; 73: 857-871Google Scholar). In brief, when a chemoreceptor binds to a repellent, it activates the cytoplasmic autophosphorylating protein kinase CheA that can transfer phosphate group to the cytoplasmic signaling protein CheY and the receptor methylesterase CheB. Phospho-CheY interacts with switch component(s) of the flagellar motor to cause its clockwise rotation; phospho-CheB demethylates chemoreceptor molecules to shut off the tumbling signal. On the other hand, binding of an attractant to a receptor causes inhibition of CheA kinase, which results in a decrease in CheY and CheB phosphorylation. The same signaling pathway (from the receptor to the flagellar motor) is utilized in thermotaxis, but the mechanism underlying thermosensing has not been elucidated.Each receptor forms a ternary complex with CheA and the coupling protein CheW (21Gegner J.A. Graham D.R. Roth A.F. Dahlquist F.W. Cell. 1992; 70: 975-982Google Scholar). Since the complex is stable in vitro (21Gegner J.A. Graham D.R. Roth A.F. Dahlquist F.W. Cell. 1992; 70: 975-982Google Scholar, 22Schuster S.C. Swanson R.V. Alex L.A. Bourret R.B. Simon M.I. Nature. 1993; 365: 343-347Google Scholar) and in vivo (23Maddock J. Shapiro L. Science. 1993; 259: 1717-1723Google Scholar), receptor-mediated control of CheA activity is thought to occur through structural changes within this receptor-CheW-CheA complex. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the thermosensing mechanism involves similar structural changes in the ternary complex to those caused by increases and decreases in temperature. It should be stressed that temperature dependence of autophosphorylation, phosphotransfer, or dephosphorylation cannot simply explain thermotaxis. Rather, the receptors seem to be primary thermosensors (2Maeda K. Imae Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 91-95Google Scholar, 3Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 360-367Google Scholar, 4Lee L. Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1988; 170: 4769-4774Google Scholar, 5Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 377-382Google Scholar, 6Nara T. Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 1120-1124Google Scholar): they fall into two classes, namely warm receptors (Tsr, Tar, and Trg) and cold receptors (Tar in the presence of attractants (see below) and Tap). A warm receptor produces attractant and repellent signals upon increases and decreases in temperature, respectively, whereas a cold receptor mediates the opposite responses to the same stimuli (6Nara T. Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 1120-1124Google Scholar).Interestingly, two lines of evidence suggest that covalent modification of the methyl-accepting sites might influence the thermosensing properties of the receptors. First, cheB-defective strains, which can respond to but cannot adapt to chemotactic stimuli, show no thermoresponse, whereas cheR-defective strains, which cannot adapt either, retain thermosensing abilities (2Maeda K. Imae Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 91-95Google Scholar, 24Imae Y. Mizuno T. Maeda K. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 368-374Google Scholar). The absence of a thermoresponse in cheB mutants might be due to the absence of deamidation and/or demethylation of the receptors. Alternatively, CheB might be involved in the thermosensing/signaling process: e.g. it might constitute a thermosensor complex with the receptor, CheW and CheA. Second, Tar produces inverted thermotactic signals in the presence of any of its specific attractants, such as aspartate and maltose (3Mizuno T. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 360-367Google Scholar, 5Lee L. Imae Y. J. Bacteriol. 1990; 172: 377-382Google Scholar). Whereas it usually functions as a warm receptor, Tar appears to be converted into a cold receptor after adapting to an attractant. Enhanced methylation of Tar has been proposed to cause this attractant-dependent conversion of thermoreceptor function.In this study, we have studied the roles of the methyl-accepting residues (Gln295, Glu302, Gln309, and Glu491: the set of the four residues will be referred to as [QEQE] throughout this paper) in the thermosensing function of Tar, by examining thermosensing profiles in the various genetic background.

It has been reported that protein kinase C (PKC) interacts at multiple sites in β-cell stimulus-secretion coupling. Nevertheless, there is still controversy concerning the importance of this enzyme in glucose-induced insulin release. The present study was undertaken to clarify whether glucose, directly, or through changes in cytoplasmic free Ca2+ concentration, [Ca2+]i, could promote translocation of PKC from the soluble to the membrane compartment. Whereas glucose, which increases [Ca2+]i, did not affect long-term distribution of PKC activity between soluble and membrane fractions, this distribution was reversibly affected acutely by the Ca2+ concentration in the extraction media. Translocation of PKC to the membrane by incubation of HIT cells for 10 min in the presence of 20 nM phorbol ester 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA) resulted in a 5-fold increase in glucose-induced insulin release. This was prevented by 50 nM concentration of the PKC inhibitor staurosporine, provided that the cells were exposed to the inhibitor before the phorbol ester. Cells pretreated with TPA demonstrated increased insulin secretion in response to glucose for several hours. This time course extended beyond the disappearance of [3H]TPA from the cells, which was complete after 1 h. Activation of PKC increased both average insulin release and the amplitude of oscillations 2-fold, but did not affect oscillation frequency. The stimulatory effect of increased PKC activity on insulin release was not matched by changes in [Ca2+]i. We suggest that stimulation of the pancreatic β-cell with glucose promotes transient translocation of certain PKC isoforms from the cytoplasm to the plasma membrane as a direct consequence of the increase in [Ca2+]i. Such a translocation may promote phosphorylation of one or several proteins involved in the regulation of the β-cell stimulus-secretion coupling. This results in potentiation of glucose-induced activation of insulin exocytosis, an effect then not mediated by an increase in [Ca2+]i per se. Hence, pulsatile insulin release can be obtained under conditions where overall [Ca2+]i does not change, challenging the view that oscillations in [Ca2+]i are indeed driving the oscillations in hormone release. It is clear that PKC operates in the pancreatic β-cell affecting the molecular mechanisms regulating both [Ca2+]i and exocytosis of insulin. The aim of the present study was to resolve the controversy whether glucose stimulation of insulin-secreting cells involved translocation of α-PKC from the cytosolic to the plasma membrane compartment and the extent to which such an effect was related to changes in [Ca2+]i and/or activation of the insulin secretory machinery. Clonal insulin-secreting tumor cells HIT-T15 were cultured in RPMI 1640 tissue culture medium supplemented with 50 microunits/ml penicillin, 50 microunits/ml streptomycin, and 10% fetal bovine serum. Cells were harvested in phosphate-buffered saline containing 0.02% EDTA. Cells were used between passages 64 and 85. HIT cells grown in 12-well culture plates (Nunc) were washed three times with Krebs-Ringer bicarbonate buffer containing (in mM) 109 NaCl, 4.6 KCl, 5 NaHCO3, 2 CaCl2, 1 MgCl2, 1.15 Na2HPO4, 0.4 KH2PO4, 0.1 MgSO4, and 20 HEPES, pH 7.4, and preincubated in identical buffer for 30 min at 37°C. Cells were then incubated in Krebs-Ringer buffer containing either 0 or 10 mM glucose for 30 min before taking samples for insulin secretion measurements. HIT cells were also harvested and sandwiched between two layers of cytodex-3 microcarrier beads (Sigma) in a column of 1 cm in diameter and with the height of 1.3 cm. The cells were perifused at a rate of 0.3 ml/min with Krebs-Ringer bicarbonate buffer. Cells were exposed to TPA for 5 min at the end of the preincubation period, to translocate PKC to the plasma membrane. Thereafter, the dynamics of glucose-induced insulin secretion were investigated and compared to that from control cells, where PKC had not been translocated to the plasma membrane with phorbol ester. Insulin was monitored by radioimmunoassay (Linco Research Inc., St. Louis, MO) in fractions of perifusion medium, which were collected at 0.5-min intervals. The effect of glucose on insulin release from HIT cells that were allowed to recover from treatment with TPA, DiC8 and DiC8 plus okadaic acid for various periods of time was also investigated. In this case, cells in culture were incubated for 10 min with 20 nM TPA, 30 min with 100 µM DiC8 or 100 µM DiC8 plus 1 µM okadaic in RPMI 1640 medium, washed once in the same RPMI 1640 medium without additions, and then incubated in similar medium until their ability to secrete insulin was studied. HIT cells were incubated for 10 min in multiwell plates in RPMI 1640 culture medium supplemented with [3H]TPA (0.1 µCi/ml) (DuPont NEN) and 20 nM cold TPA. Following incubation, TPA was removed and cells were rinsed and incubated with RPMI 1640 medium without phorbol ester. Cells were extracted in Krebs buffer containing 0.1% Triton X-100 after various intervals, to determine amounts of associated TPA. Samples of medium were also collected prior to extraction of cells. 3H was determined in a Beckman scintillation counter. Cells were loaded with 2 µM fura-2/AM, in a HEPES-buffered Krebs medium (23Longo E.A. Tornheim K. Deeney J.T. Varnum B.A. Tillotson T. Prentki M. Corkey B.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 9314-9319Google Scholar) containing no glucose, for 20-30 min at 37°C. Fluorescence signals of suspensions of HIT cells were recorded using a Hitachi F-2000 spectrofluorometer, equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a temperature-statted cell holder. Wavelengths used were 340/380 nm excitation and 510 nm emission. For single cell measurements of [Ca2+]i in a microscopic system, HIT cells were grown on glass coverslips and loaded with fura-2, as described above. Thereafter, the coverslips were mounted in an open chamber which was placed onto the stage of a Zeiss IM-35 fluorescence microscope. After obtaining baseline recordings, the cells were stimulated with 10 mM glucose while [Ca2+]i was monitored continuously, using a time-sharing fluorometer with output to a video camera (IONOPTIX Corp., Boston, MA). [Ca2+]i was estimated by performing a pixel by pixel ratio between images, where background was subtracted, using IONOPTIX software. HIT cells were incubated in Petri dishes in Krebs-Ringer bicarbonate buffer for 30-60 min. Thereafter, they were harvested and incubated, while shaking, for an additional 10 min in similar buffer. Aliquots of cells were then transferred to microcentrifuge tubes, quickly pelleted, and placed on ice. In some cases, cells were stimulated with 10 mM glucose, for 5-10 min, prior to being aliquoted. Incubation media were aspirated and replaced with 200 µl of cold Ca2+/EGTA buffers (World Precision Instruments) ranging from 0.01 to 3.2 µM free Ca2+ supplemented with 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 50 µg/ml leupeptin, and 0.35%β-mercaptoethanol. Cells were disrupted by sonication at 4°C. Cell homogenates were then centrifuged at 165,000 × g for 35 min in a Beckman model airfuge. The supernatant was taken as the cytosolic fraction while the pellet was resuspended in the same Ca2+/EGTA buffer as the first extraction with the addition of 0.2% Triton X-100. The pellet was then vortexed vigorously and centrifuged at 14,000 × g for 10 min. This supernatant was taken as the pellet fraction. Triton X-100 was left out of the resuspension buffer in those experiments in which the pellet was washed. PKC activity was determined as the difference between histone phosphorylation in the presence and absence of phosphatidylserine (20 µg/ml), DAG (2 µg/ml), and Ca2+ (0.6 mM). Cytosol and pellet fractions, prepared as described above, were diluted 1:15 in EGTA extraction buffer containing 50 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 2.5 mM EGTA, 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 50 µg of leupeptin, and 0.35%β-mercaptoethanol. 1-2 µg of protein (12.5 µl) were incubated for 30 min in the presence of 125 µl of 25 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 10 mM MgCl2, 0.01% Triton X-100, 0.16 mg/ml histone (Type III S), 50 µM ATP (1-2 µCi of [γ-32]ATP/assay tube) (24Majumdar S. The reaction was stopped by spotting the reaction medium onto filter paper and washing with 1 liter of ice-cold 10% trichloroacetic acid containing 10 mM pyrophosphate. Filters were dried and counted without scintillant in a Beckman model scintillation counter. PKC mass was determined by subjecting the protein sample to SDS-polyacrylamide electrophoresis (25Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Google Scholar), followed by transfer to nitrocellulose filter (Hoeffer). The nitrocellulose filter was incubated with an α-PKC-specific polyclonal rat antibody (Life Technologies, Inc.), followed by an anti-rat monoclonal rabbit antibody linked to horseradish peroxidase (Amersham), as described by Towbin (26Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Google Scholar). Protein bands were detected using an ECL Western blotting detection kit (Amersham). Statistical analyses were performed with Student's t test for unpaired data. Upon incubation of HIT cells in modified Krebs-Ringer buffer, containing 0 or 10 mM glucose, for 10 min followed by extraction in buffer containing either 0.01 or 3.2 µM free Ca2+, glucose did not affect sustained distribution of PKC activity between cytosolic and membrane fractions, as determined by incorporation of [32P]ATP into histone (Fig. 1). However, it was of interest to note that this distribution was affected by the actual Ca2+ concentration in the extraction media (Fig. 1), suggesting that the extraction process could mask rapidly reversible changes that had occurred in the cell. The total PKC activity was not changed by glucose or the concentration of Ca2+ in the extraction media. To establish a possible effect of Ca2+ on PKC translocation, HIT cells were extracted in different Ca2+/EGTA buffers and separated into cytosolic and membrane fractions, and relative distribution of enzyme activity was determined. Cells disrupted in extraction buffers containing increasing concentrations of free Ca2+ (0.01, 0.32, and 3.2 µM, respectively) exhibited increased PKC activity in their membrane fractions (Fig. 2A). Cytosolic PKC activity in these extracts decreased concomitantly. Western blot analysis using an anti-α-PKC specific antibody showed that the change in total PKC activity was accompanied by a qualitatively similar change in the distribution of the mass of the α-PKC isoform (Fig. 2B). The translocation of PKC, resulting from increased free Ca2+ concentrations in the extraction media, was readily reversible, as clearly shown in experiments where membrane fractions from the high Ca2+ buffer (3.2 µM, Fig. 3A) were washed in buffer with a low Ca2+ concentration (0.01 µM). Under these experimental conditions, PKC activity dissociated from the membrane fraction (Fig. 3B). When washing was performed in buffer containing a high Ca2+ concentration, PKC activity remained in the membrane fraction (Fig. 3D). These results are consistent with the idea that glucose, by raising [Ca2+]i, can indirectly affect distribution of PKC activity in the β-cell. The PKC inhibitor staurosporine, at a concentration of 50 nM, prevented TPA from enhancing glucose-induced insulin secretion, provided that the cells were exposed to the PKC inhibitor prior to stimulation with TPA. These results document a strong synergism between glucose and PKC activation and suggest that PKC may phosphorylate a substrate that remains phosphorylated for a prolonged period of time and is not inhibited by staurosporine. Thus, only brief activation of PKC allows for enhanced glucose-induced insulin secretion. However, we cannot exclude the possibility that the phorbol ester somehow induces a conformational change of PKC so that it can no longer be inhibited by staurosporine (27Slater S.J. Kelly M.B. Taddeo F.J. Rubin E. Stubbs C.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17160-17165Google Scholar). 4-α-Phorbol, a nonactive phorbol ester, had no effect on insulin release (data not shown). In order to further characterize the molecular mechanism whereby the putative PKC substrate potentiates glucose-induced insulin release, a time course of recovery from stimulus treatment was performed. HIT cells were pretreated with 20 nM TPA for 10 min or 100 µM concentration of the metabolically active DiC8 for 30 min and allowed to recover for various periods of time before testing the ability of the cells to secrete insulin in response to 10 mM glucose (Fig. 5). Cells that had been pretreated with TPA demonstrated an increased insulin secretion in response to glucose for a prolonged (several hours) period of time (Fig. 5A). A second addition of TPA, after recovery of normal glucose-induced insulin secretion, also resulted in enhanced hormone release in response to the sugar (data not shown), demonstrating that the recovery could not simply be explained by an overall loss of glucose responsiveness. A shorter time course of recovery of enhanced insulin secretion was obtained when DiC8 was used to stimulate hormone release (Fig. 5B). In this case, cells exhibited normal glucose-induced insulin release within 30 min of removal of DiC8. Interestingly, exposure of the cells to 1 µM phosphatase inhibitor okadaic acid, prior to the addition of DiC8 (data not shown), extended the recovery phase of normal glucose-induced insulin release to at least 1 h. It is noteworthy that the time course of recovery of glucose-induced insulin release after stimulation with TPA did not correlate with the disappearance of [3H]TPA from the cells (Fig. 5C). [3H]TPA was redistributed from the cells to the media within 1 h after removal of the phorbol ester from the incubation buffer. Although the residual activity was close to background, TPA may still be bound to PKC and thereby maintain phosphorylation and activation of the substrate. The discrepancy in effects between TPA and the readily metabolizable DiC8, are in line with previous findings demonstrating that DAG and TPA bind with different affinities and at different sites as well as inducing distinct activated conformational forms of PKC (27Slater S.J. Kelly M.B. Taddeo F.J. Rubin E. Stubbs C.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17160-17165Google Scholar). Hence, both the TPA data and the data demonstrating that the effect of DiC8 was prolonged by pretreatment with okadaic acid may be viewed in support of the notion that PKC phosphorylates a substrate that maintains a long lasting function in the β-cell and hence can be responsible for the prolonged stimulatory effect of glucose on insulin release. Next, we were interested in clarifying whether the long-lasting stimulatory effect on insulin release, subsequent to exposure of the cells for 5 min to 20 nM TPA, affected glucose-induced (10 mM) pulsatility in insulin release from column-perifused HIT cells. Whereas frequency of oscillations was unaffected, both average insulin release and amplitude of oscillations were increased by 2-fold (Fig. 6). Since PKC is a well-known potentiator of glucose-induced insulin release, increases in insulin release were expected. More interestingly, the frequency of oscillations was not affected by PKC. Although the molecular mechanisms that directly regulate pulsatility in insulin release remain to be established, we have reasons to believe that enzymes in the glycolytic pathway play essential roles (28Nilsson T. Schultz V. Berggren P.-O. Corkey B.E. Tornheim K. Biochem. J. 1996; 314: 91-94Google Scholar). Hence, if this is true, our results suggest that these enzymes do not serve as direct substrates for PKC-induced phosphorylation in the pancreatic β-cell. It is of interest to note that the stimulatory effect of increased PKC activity on glucose-induced insulin release in HIT cells was not associated with further increases in [Ca2+]i (Fig. 7). On the contrary, the net increase in [Ca2+]i subsequent to K+-stimulation as measured in suspensions of HIT cells in a cuvette in a spectrofluorometer (Fig. 7A) was significantly less in those cells that were exposed to TPA. Moreover, the increase in [Ca2+]i normally obtained subsequent to activation of the PLC system, in the present study 0.2 µM bombesin was used as an agonist, was also suppressed in the presence of the phorbol ester (Fig. 7B). In this case, there was a decrease even in basal [Ca2+]i. When [Ca2+]i was measured in single cells in a microscope-based imaging system (Fig. 7C), there was no potentiation of the glucose-induced oscillatory pattern subsequent to the addition of TPA. On the contrary, if anything, the phorbol ester seemed to suppress the oscillations in [Ca2+]i, which is in marked contrast to the effects obtained in the insulin release experiments where TPA dramatically increased the amplitude of the oscillations (cf. Fig. 6). These findings indeed support the notion (22Zaitsev S.V. Efendić S. Arkhammar P. Bertorello A.M. Berggren P.-O. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 9712-9716Google Scholar, 29Berggren P.-O. Larsson O. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1994; 22: 12-18Google Scholar) that there is not always a direct coupling between overall changes in [Ca2+]i and insulin release. Over the years a number of studies have been performed to clarify the role of PKC in the insulin secretory process. For this purpose, different approaches have been taken, such as direct activation of PKC by low concentrations (10 nM) of the phorbol ester TPA or down-regulation of the enzyme by prolonged treatment with high concentrations of TPA (200 nM) (19Arkhammar P. Nilsson T. Welsh M. Welsh N. Berggren P.-O. Biochem. J. 1989; 264: 207-215Google Scholar, 30Nishizuka Y. Nature. 1984; 308: 693-698Google Scholar). These effects of the phorbol ester reflect interaction with the classic PKC and certain novel PKC isoforms (3Nishizuka Y. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 484-496Google Scholar) and indicate that such isoforms can have important modulatory effects on the insulin secretory process. In the normal pancreatic β-cell, activation of PKC with TPA enhances glucose-induced insulin release without further increasing [Ca2+]i (19Arkhammar P. Nilsson T. Welsh M. Welsh N. Berggren P.-O. Biochem. J. 1989; 264: 207-215Google Scholar, 22Zaitsev S.V. Efendić S. Arkhammar P. Bertorello A.M. Berggren P.-O. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 9712-9716Google Scholar). The dissociation between increases in [Ca2+]i and insulin exocytosis in response to PKC activation has been further substantiated by experiments demonstrating a PKC-mediated increase in insulin release under conditions where there was no change in [Ca2+]i when both parameters were measured simultaneously in a perifusion system (22Zaitsev S.V. Efendić S. Arkhammar P. Bertorello A.M. Berggren P.-O. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 9712-9716Google Scholar). The present study clearly shows that translocation of α-PKC from the cytosol to the plasma membrane is not dependent on glucose per se, but rather on an elevation in [Ca2+]i, which is in accordance with a permissive role for Ca2+ in the stimulatory effect of the kinase on exocytosis of insulin. The transient nature of Ca2+-mediated translocation would explain previous, apparently contradictory, observations of PKC translocation using in situ histochemical techniques (7Ganesan S. Calle R. Zawalich K. Greenawalt K. Zawalich W.S. Shulman G.I. Rasmussen H. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 313-324Google Scholar, 8Ganesan S. Calle R. Zawalich K. Smallwood J.I. Zawalich W.S. Rasmussen H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 9893-9897Google Scholar), on the one hand, and failure to document enhanced glucose-stimulated PKC association with the membrane fraction following cell fractionation (12Easom R.A. Hughes J.H. Landt M. Wolf B.A. Turk J. McDaniel M.L. Biochem. J. 1989; 164: 27-33Google Scholar, 18Howell S.L. Jones P.M. Persaud S.J. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1990; 18: 114-116Google Scholar), on the other hand. The fact that this translocation of PKC was so strictly dependent on Ca2+, and reversible upon withdrawal of the ion, may suggest that the activity of the enzyme oscillates in parallel with oscillations in [Ca2+]i. If so, this might represent a component in the molecular regulation of the pulsatility in insulin release. A similar dependence for Ca2+, with regard to subcellular distribution of PKC, has been demonstrated in human neutrophils (31Phillips W.A. Fujiki T. Rossi M.W. Korchak H.M. Johnston Jr., R.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 8361-8365Google Scholar). In that study, the authors suggested that the distribution of PKC between cytosol and membrane is a dynamic equilibrium controlled by levels of free Ca2+. The extent to which translocation of PKC to the plasma membrane implies that the enzyme has to be present in the membrane throughout the stimulatory event is not clear. Alternatively, the possibility that it is sufficient that PKC induces phosphorylation of one or several proteins that remain phosphorylated during exocytosis and are then responsible for promoting transport, targeting, and fusion of insulin secretory granules with the plasma membrane must be considered. The results obtained with the phorbol ester TPA in the present study do not clearly differentiate between these two possibilities. The fact that TPA only needed to be present for a short period of time prior to glucose stimulation, in order to potentiate not only insulin release but also its oscillatory pattern, suggests phosphorylation of some regulatory proteins that are then responsible for mediating this potentiation and supports the second possibility. Interestingly, the stimulatory effect of the phorbol ester on glucose-induced insulin release remained for at least 3 h, indicating that the phosphorylated proteins stay phosphorylated and hence active for a prolonged period of time. However, although removal of TPA from the plasma membrane seemed to be complete after 1 h, we cannot exclude the possibility that some TPA remained bound to PKC and thereby maintained phosphorylation and activation of the substrate. Speaking against this possibility are the results by Szallasi et al. (32Szallasi Z. Smith C.B. Blumberg P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27159-27162Google Scholar), showing that cellular dissociation of phorbol ester leads to rapid redistribution to the cytosol of α-PKC in mouse keratinocytes. Measurement of glucose-induced insulin release from cells that were pre-exposed to the short-chain PKC activator DiC8 or DiC8 plus the phosphatase inhibitor okadaic acid, may suggest that PKC indeed induced phosphorylation of one or several regulatory proteins that maintain a brief stimulatory effect on insulin exocytosis. The fact that cells pre-exposed to DiC8 recovered with regard to potentiation of glucose-induced insulin release after 30 min and that this recovery was delayed in the presence of okadaic acid, speaks in favor of dephosphorylation of actual PKC substrates being responsible for the rather rapid loss in potentiation of glucose-induced insulin release subsequent to stimulation with DiC8. The different response pattern obtained with TPA and DiC8 may reflect distinct interactions of these compounds with PKC (27Slater S.J. Kelly M.B. Taddeo F.J. Rubin E. Stubbs C.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17160-17165Google Scholar). Physiological DAG activators of PKC have chain lengths of 16 to 20 carbons, are considerably more lipophilic than DiC8, and would be expected to be associated with membranes for a longer period of time. The finding that PKC activation suppressed K+-induced increases in [Ca2+]i in HIT cells is likely to reflect pronounced activation of the Ca2+-outward transport system (33Berggren P.-O. Arkhammar P. Nilsson T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1989; 165: 416-421Google Scholar). Hence, regulation of [Ca2+]i is a complex function of multiple Ca2+ carriers such that outward transport of Ca2+, at least partly promoted by a Ca2+-ATPase, is highly effective in restoring [Ca2+]i in insulin-secreting cells under conditions when PKC is activated. Although activation of PKC with TPA suppresses the activity of the PLC system and thereby the generation of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate, as has been reported earlier (10Arkhammar P. Juntti-Berggren L. Larsson O. Welsh M. Nånberg E. Sjöholm Å. Köhler M. Berggren P.-O. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 2743-2749Google Scholar) and which was also verified in the present study using bombesin as an agonist, the kinase does not interfere with either intracellular buffering of [Ca2+]i or the ability of inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate to release Ca2+ from internal stores (19Arkhammar P. Nilsson T. Welsh M. Welsh N. Berggren P.-O. Biochem. J. 1989; 264: 207-215Google Scholar). Activation of PKC did not enhance oscillations in [Ca2+]i in HIT cells. Moreover, we have previously shown that activation of the kinase on the contrary suppresses [Ca2+]i oscillations in normal β-cells (34Kindmark H. Köhler M. Efendić S. Rorsman P. Larsson O. Berggren P.-O. FEBS Lett. 1992; 303: 85-90Google Scholar). When discussing a possible role for PKC in the β-cell stimulus-secretion coupling, it should be borne in mind that this kinase constitutes a family of enzymes that may have diverse functions, distinct intracellular localization as well as varying cell-specific expression, and sensitivity to PKC activators. It is noteworthy that the HIT cells used in the present study have a number of features, with regard to effects of PKC activation, that are similar to those previously reported in normal β-cells and clonal insulin-producing RINm5F cells, thus making them an appropriate model to define the sites of action of PKC in the complex chain of events constituting β-cell signal transduction. The underlying molecular mechanism responsible for the potentiating effect of PKC on the oscillatory pattern in insulin release is at the moment not clear. Obviously, the present study does not support a major role for changes in [Ca2+]i in this context, but on the contrary reinforces the notion (22Zaitsev S.V. Efendić S. Arkhammar P. Bertorello A.M. Berggren P.-O. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 9712-9716Google Scholar, 29Berggren P.-O. Larsson O. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1994; 22: 12-18Google Scholar) that there indeed exist a number of situations where there is a clear dissociation between changes in [Ca2+]i and regulation of insulin exocytosis. The fact that only the amplitude, but not the frequency, of the oscillations was affected suggests that the effect of PKC reflects recruitment of cells or synchronization of the secretory activity in a large number of cells in the insulin release column perifusion system, thereby enhancing an already existing oscillatory pattern in hormone release. The extent to which such a synchronization involves a more efficient cell to cell coupling through gap junctional proteins within clusters of HIT cells and/or release of a synchronizer molecule merits further investigation. A direct effect of PKC on the oscillator, by whatever mechanism, should have affected the frequency of the oscillatory pattern in insulin release. However, a more simple explanation for the effect of PKC on insulin release is that the kinase potentiates an existing oscillatory secretory activity in the individual cells by, for example, effective phosphorylation of one or several proteins directly regulating exocytosis in general and known to exist in the pancreatic β-cell (35Jacobsson G. Bean A.J. Scheller R.H. Juntti-Berggren L. Deeney J.T. Berggren P.-O. Meister B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 12487-12491Google Scholar).

The three-dimensional structure of the human β3β3 dimeric alcohol dehydrogenase (β3) was determined to 2.4-Å resolution. β3 was crystallized as a ternary complex with the coenzyme NAD+ and the competitive inhibitor 4-iodopyrazole. β3 is a polymorphic variant at ADH2 that differs from β1 by a single amino acid substitution of Arg-369 → Cys. The available x-ray structures of mammalian alcohol dehydrogenases show that the side chain of Arg-369 forms an ion pair with the NAD(H) pyrophosphate to stabilize the E·NAD(H) complex. The Cys-369 side chain of β3 cannot form this interaction. The three-dimensional structures of β3 and β1 are virtually identical, with the exception that Cys-369 and two water molecules in β3 occupy the position of Arg-369 in β1. The two waters occupy the same positions as two guanidino nitrogens of Arg-369. Hence, the number of hydrogen bonding interactions between the enzyme and NAD(H) are the same for both isoenzymes. However, β3 differs from β1 by the loss of the electrostatic interaction between the NAD(H) pyrophosphate and the Arg-369 side chain. The equilibrium dissociation constants of β3 for NAD+ and NADH are 350-fold and 4000-fold higher, respectively, than those for β1. These changes correspond to binding free energy differences of 3.5 kcal/mol for NAD+ and 4.9 kcal/mol for NADH. Thus, the Arg-369 → Cys substitution of β3 isoenzyme destabilizes the interaction between coenzyme and β3 alcohol dehydrogenase. Actions of thyroid hormones (THs) are determined by intracellular free hormone concentration. Here we report that enhanced TH extrusion via a saturable, cold-sensitive mechanism lowers intracellular TH and causes TH resistance in hepatoma cells. Since these cells overexpress multidrug resistance P-glycoproteins and TH extrusion and resistance are blunted by verapamil, P-glycoproteins may mediate this resistance. Verapamil-inhibitable TH efflux was also found in primary hepatocytes, cardiocytes, and fibroblasts. These findings demonstrate that TH extrusion can modulate TH availability and action in mammalian cells. Actions of thyroid hormones (THs) are determined by intracellular free hormone concentration. In the absence of co-transfected TRs, CAT production in HTC parental cells was not stimulated by T3 (10−7M) indicating the absence or very low content of endogenous TRs in these cells. HTC-R cells required approximately 10-fold higher T3 concentration than HTC parental cells for half-maximal induction of relative CAT activity (EC50 2.2 ± 0.4), range 0.5-3.8 nM, n = 7 for HTC cells compared to 17.9 ± 4.6, range 8.0-40.7 nM, n = 8 for HTC-R cells (p < 0.01) (Fig. 1A). The absolute CAT activity, however, did not differ between HTC and HTC-R cells. Moreover, in contrast to TH, HTC-R and HTC parental cells exhibited equal sensitivity to estradiol (Fig. 1B), indicating selectivity in the HTC-R cells' hormone resistance.We then studied TH uptake to test whether the TH resistance of HTC-R cells is due to altered TH transport. Although initial uptake (to 5 min) of T3 by HTC-R cells was at least as rapid as for HTC cells (Fig. 2, inset), steady state T3 accumulation by HTC-R cells was significantly less (Fig. 2). T3 efflux curves were bi-exponential, showing a rapid initial component and a slower terminal component (Fig. 3A). T3 efflux could be described by a two-compartment model; a small rapidly exchanging compartment (postulated to represent plasma membrane binding) and a larger, more slowly exchanging compartment (postulated to be intracellular). In both cell types the slow compartment comprised at least 95% of total cellular T3. The difference in steady state T3 content between HTC and HTC-R cells was accounted for by the difference in fractional efflux rates from the larger, slow compartment (Table I). As shown in Fig. 3A and Table I, the fractional rate of T3 efflux was much greater from the HTC-R cells than from HTC cells at 37°C. The AML1 gene encodes DNA-binding proteins that contain the runt homology domain and is found at the breakpoints of t(8;21), t(3;21), and t(12;21) translocations associated with myelogenous leukemias. AML1 heterodimerizes with PEBP2β/CBFβ, resulting in the enhanced affinity with DNA. The runt homology domain is responsible for binding with DNA and heterodimerizing with PEBP2β/CBFβ. AML1 is suggested to perform a pivotal role in myeloid cell differentiation, whereas it can cause neoplastic transformation when overexpressed in fibroblasts. In this study, we demonstrated that the reducing reagent, dithiothreitol (DTT), markedly enhances the DNA binding of AML1 expressed in COS7 cells. Oxidation by diamide or modification by N-ethylmaleimide of the free sulfhydryl residues inhibited the interaction of AML1 with DNA. The diamide effect was reversible with excess of DTT, whereas DTT could not restore the DNA binding of AML1 treated with N-ethylmaleimide. Site-directed mutagenesis of the amino acid residue 72, a highly conserved cysteine in the runt homology domain of AML1, to serine almost completely abolished DNA binding without altering the interaction with PEBP2β/CBFβ. This substitution also impaired transactivation through the consensus DNA sequence and transformation of fibroblasts induced by AML1b. These data indicate an essential role of the conserved cysteine residue in DNA binding of AML1, and it is possible that the redox state of AML1 could contribute to the regulation of its function. The multisubunit signal peptidase catalyzes the cleavage of signal peptides and the degradation of some membrane proteins within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The only subunit of this enzyme functionally examined to date, yeast Sec11p, is related to signal peptidase I from bacteria. Since bacterial signal peptidase is capable of processing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic signal sequences as a monomer, it is unclear why the analogous enzyme in the ER contains proteins unrelated to signal peptidase I. To address this issue, the gene encoding Spc1p, the yeast homologue to mammalian SPC12, is isolated from the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Spc1p co-purifies and genetically interacts with Sec11p, but unlike Sec11p, Spc1p is not required for cell growth or the proteolytic processing of tested proteins in yeast. This indicates that only a subset of the ER signal peptidase subunits is required for signal peptidase and protein degradation activities in vivo. Through both genetic and biochemical criteria, Spc1p appears, however, to be important for efficient signal peptidase activity. This study describes the first in vivo characterization of a signal peptidase subunit other than subunits from the bacterial signal peptidase I protein family. Spc1p, the yeast homologue of mammalian SPC12, co-purifies with Sec11p, an essential subunit of the yeast signal peptidase complex, and exhibits the following two genetic interactions with Sec11p. Overexpression of Spc1p suppresses the temperature-sensitive sec11 mutation, and the spc1 and sec11 mutations are synthetically lethal. Despite these genetic and physical interactions with an essential component of the signal peptidase complex, Spc1p is nonessential for the proteolytic cleavage of tested precursor proteins and the degradation of abnormal membrane protein AHDK2. Our results are therefore in good agreement with in vitro data obtained from analysis of enzymatically active avian signal peptidase which contains a Sec11p homologue but lacks a Spc1p homologue (10Baker R.K. Lively M.O. Biochemistry. 1987; 26: 8561-8567Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Furthermore, our results agree with topology studies (17Kalies K.-U. Hartmann E. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 4325-4329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (41) Google Scholar), suggesting that mammalian SPC12 does not contribute amino acids to the catalytic site of signal peptidase. While Spc1p is probably not itself catalytic, we show that Spc1p is important for increasing the efficiency of signal peptidase action. Specifically, overexpression of Spc1p promotes cleavage of the preKar2p signal peptide in the temperature-sensitive sec11 mutant, and depletion of Spc1p exacerbates the sec11 defect. In addition, preKar2p accumulates in Δspc1 mutant cells expressing abnormal membrane protein AHDK2. The latter result argues that competition exists between preKar2p and AHDK2 for the active site of signal peptidase and supports the idea that abnormal membrane protein AHDK2 is degraded through a signal peptidase-dependent pathway. Since enzymatically active signal peptidase I purified from E. coli contains only one polypeptide, it was expected that Spc1p, which is unrelated to signal peptidase I, would be important for activities other than signal peptide cleavages. Instead, our data suggest that Spc1p is important for efficient signal peptidase activity. We thus conclude that either bacterial cells contain a homologue of Spc1p that does not bind tightly to signal peptidase I or eukaryotic cells have a particular requirement for noncatalytic subunits such as Spc1p. This requirement could derive from the fact that, in contrast to bacterial signal peptidase, ER signal peptidase must recognize signal peptides of proteins targeted to various compartments of the secretory pathway. Since signal peptides vary in length and primary sequence, the diversity of signal peptides recognized by the ER enzyme is probably greater than that encountered in bacteria. In addition to the demand placed on ER signal peptidase to efficiently process a variety of precursor proteins, the multisubunit signal peptidase complex is also involved in protein degradation. The observed accumulation of preKar2p in the Δspc1 mutant expressing abnormal membrane protein AHDK2 suggests that Spc1p may function to ensure efficient signal peptide cleavages in situations where the protein degradation activity within the ER is high. CTG·CAG, CGG·CCG, and AAG·CTT triplet repeats proximal to or in disease genes expand by a non-Mendelian genetic process to cause several human hereditary syndromes. As part of our physical, biological, and genetic studies on the 10 possible triplet repeats, we discovered that the TTA·TAA repeat, isolated from the upstream region of the variant surface glycoprotein gene of Trypanosoma brucei, shows a propensity to adopt a non-H bonded structure under appropriate conditions. The other nine triplet repeat sequences do not exhibit this property. (TTA·TAA)n, where n = 90, 60, 30, and 18, cloned into pUC19 was studied by chemical and enzymatic probes as well as two-dimensional gel electrophoretic analyses under a variety of conditions. The helix opening was observed for all four inserts in supercoiled plasmids as a function of temperature, pH, metal ions, and buffer conditions using OsO4, diethyl pyrocarbonate, and chloroacetaldehyde probes. This unusual property of the TTA·TAA repeat suggests that it plays a different role from the other nine triplet repeats in gene expression. We report the identification and biochemical characterization of an endogenous m5 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (mAChR) in the A2058 human melanoma cell line. This is the first demonstration of a m5AChR outside the central nervous system. The unusual effector coupling of this endogenous m5AChR is presented. The coding region amplified by polymerase chain reaction was identical to the known m5AChR sequence. Binding studies indicated a Kd of 99 ± 6 pM and a Bmax of 45 ± 4 fmol/mg membrane protein. This m5AChR coupled to stimulation of arachidonic acid release and to a 50% inhibition of forskolin-stimulated cAMP accumulation. The inhibition of cAMP production was insensitive to pertussis toxin treatment, but was dependent upon extracellular calcium. In contrast to the odd mAChR pattern, no cAMP was produced in response to carbachol (CC) stimulation. Moreover, no release of inositol phosphates could be measured after CC treatment despite the presence of at least 2 phospholipase C isoforms in A2058 cells. CC-stimulated arachidonic acid release (EC50 = 17.8 ± 0.1 µM) was dependent upon external Ca2+, with marked reduction after coincubation with EGTA, Co2+, or high doses of verapamil (IC50 = 166 µM) or diltiazem (IC50 = 243 µM). Brief exposure to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate augmented CC-stimulated arachidonic acid release, whereas prolonged phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate treatment resulted in down-regulation of release. Activation of the m5AChR resulted in Ca2+ influx that was attenuated by muscarinic antagonism and removal of extracellular Ca2+. A2058 cells exposed to CC had no alteration of cell shape or growth potential in monolayer culture, however, a statistically significant reduction in density-independent growth was observed over the range of CC concentrations from 0.1 to 100 µM. This endogenous m5AChR has a novel signal transduction coupling profile and receptor activation reduces clonogenic potential. Secretogranin III (SgIII) is an acidic protein of unknown function that is present in the storage vesicles of many neuroendocrine cells. It is coexpressed with the prohormone proopiomelanocortin in the intermediate pituitary of Xenopus laevis. We developed an antiserum to investigate the biosynthesis of SgIII in pulse-chase incubated Xenopus neurointermediate lobes. SgIII was synthesized as a 61- or 63-kDa (N-glycosylated) protein and processed to a 48-kDa form which, in turn, was partially cleaved to fragments of 28 and 20 kDa. The 48-, 28-, and 20-kDa cleavage products, but not their precursors, were secreted. This secretion is regulated and can be blocked in parallel with that of proopiomelanocortin-derived peptides by the hypothalamic factors dopamine, γ-aminobutyric acid, and neuropeptide Y. Coexpression of Xenopus SgIII with prohormone convertase (PC)1 or PC2 in transfected fibroblasts was sufficient to reconstitute the processing events observed in the neurointermediate lobes. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed that Xenopus SgIII is cleaved at two dibasic sites, namely Lys68-Arg69 and Arg237-Arg238. Pulse-chase incubations of lobes with Na2[35S]SO4 showed that SgIII is sulfated in the trans-Golgi network before it is processed. Finally, SgIII processing was found in several neuroendocrine cell types from various species. We conclude that SgIII is a precursor protein and that the intact molecule can only have an intracellular function, whereas an extracellular role can only be attributed to its cleavage products. A hallmark of neuroendocrine cells is their ability to synthesize, store, and release biologically active peptides in a regulated fashion. Most neuropeptides and peptide hormones are generated from inactive precursor proteins that are proteolytically processed at pairs of basic amino acids and often further modified to yield a functional product (1Halban P.A. Irminger J.C. Biochem. J. 1994; 299: 1-18Google Scholar). The bulk of these modifications occurs subsequent to the sorting of peptide precursors, along with their processing enzymes, into secretory granules. These specialized storage vesicles deliver their contents to the cell surface only in response to an external signal. Besides peptides and processing enzymes, secretory granules contain a group of acidic secretory proteins, collectively known as the granin (chromogranin/secretogranin) family (2Huttner W.B. Gerdes H.H. Rosa P. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1991; 16: 27-30Google Scholar). Within this family, only chromogranin A (CgA) 1The abbreviations used are: CgchromograninBFAbrefeldin AGABAγ-aminobutyric acidNILneurointermediate lobeNPYneuropeptide YPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisPCprohormone convertasePOMCproopiomelanocortinSgsecretograninTGNtrans-Golgi network. and CgB (secretogranin I, SgI) show a structural relationship. Granins are characterized by acidic isoelectric points and by the presence of numerous pairs of basic amino acids, some of which are used by endoproteolytic enzymes. Unlike peptide hormones and processing enzymes, which have well defined functions in the neuroendocrine system, the physiological role of the granins is unclear. One hypothesis is that granins themselves are precursors for biologically active peptides. This notion is supported by the observation that peptides derived from proteolytic processing of CgA and SgII are capable of modulating secretion in an autocrine or paracrine manner (3Galindo E. Rill A. Bader M.F. Aunis D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 1426-1430Google Scholar, 4Tatemoto K. Efendic S. Mutt V. Makk G. Feistner G.J. Barchar J.D. Nature. 1986; 324: 476-478Google Scholar, 5Saria A. Troger J. Kirchmair R. Fischer-Colbrie R. Hogue-Angeletti R. Winkler H. Neuroscience. 1993; 54: 1-4Google Scholar). However, recent experimental evidence suggests that at least some granins function intracellularly as helper proteins in the sorting and proteolytic processing of prohormones. For instance, overexpression of CgB in anterior pituitary-derived AtT20 cells was found to promote the aggregation-dependent sorting of proopiomelanocortin (POMC)-derived cleavage products into secretory granules (6Huttner W.B. Natori S. Curr. Biol. 1995; 5: 242-245Google Scholar). Furthermore, the neuroendocrine protein 7B2 (SgV) physically interacts with the proform of prohormone convertase PC2 and seems to regulate both transport and activation of this processing enzyme in the secretory pathway (7Martens G.J.M. One of the granins whose function has remained elusive is SgIII. Its transcript was originally identified from rat brain during a search for mRNAs that are exclusively expressed in the central nervous system (11Ottiger H.-P. Battenberg E.F. Tsou A.P. Bloom F.E. Sutcliffe J.G. J. Neurosci. 1990; 10: 3135-3147Google Scholar). The protein was detected in many brain areas, especially in neurons participating in auditory, olfactory, and extrapyramidal motor functions, as well as in those related to the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Moreover, SgIII was found in cells of the intermediate and anterior pituitary, whereas ultrastructural studies demonstrated its presence in intracellular vesicles (11Ottiger H.-P. Battenberg E.F. Tsou A.P. Bloom F.E. Sutcliffe J.G. J. Neurosci. 1990; 10: 3135-3147Google Scholar). Genetic ablation of the gene in mice revealed that animals lacking SgIII survive without any obvious impairment in viability, fertility, or locomotor behavior (12Kingsley D.M. Rinchick E.M. Russell L.B. Ottiger H.-P. Sutcliffe J.G. Copeland N.G. Jenkins N.A. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 395-399Google Scholar). Consequently, many of the cell types that normally express SgIII can function in the absence of this protein, perhaps because its physiological role can be replaced by that of another gene product. Recently, we cloned the first nonmammalian homolog of SgIII from the amphibian Xenopus laevis. This was achieved by a differential screening strategy designed to identify genes coexpressed with POMC in the melanotrope cells of the intermediate pituitary (13Holthuis J.C.M. Jansen E.J.R. Van Riel M.C.H.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Cell Sci. 1995; 108: 3295-3305Google Scholar). In these cells, the production levels of POMC-derived melanophore-stimulating peptides can be manipulated in vivo by changing the background color of the toad. When the animal is placed on a black background, the mRNA levels of SgIII in the intermediate pituitary increase dramatically (up to 35-fold) and in parallel with that of POMC (30-fold increase) (14Holthuis J.C.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Neurochem. 1996; (in press)Google Scholar), suggesting that SgIII has a role in the production and release of peptide hormones. In the present study, we investigate the biosynthesis of SgIII in Xenopus melanotropes, taking advantage of the high metabolic activity of these cells in black-adapted animals. We find that SgIII is a sulfated precursor protein and demonstrate that proteolytic processing occurs at two dibasic sites that are recognized by the prohormone convertases PC1 and PC2. Chem. 1986; 261: 11398-11403Google Scholar), whereas monensin is known to interfere with protein transport between Golgi compartments (23Tartakoff A.M. Cell. 1983; 32: 1026-1028Google Scholar). Only the 48- and 20-kDa forms could be detected in the chase medium. This finding suggests that SgIII processing in Xenopus melanotropes starts in the immature secretory granules. The prohormone convertases PC1 (also termed PC3) and PC2 represent two neuroendocrine-specific members of the subtilisin family of endoproteases and are responsible for the proteolytic conversion of a wide range of prohormones and other peptide precursors at pairs of basic amino acids (28Steiner D.F. Smeekens S.P. Ohagi S. Chan S.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 23435-23438Google Scholar, 29Seidah N.G. Chrétien M. Methods Enzymol. 1994; 244: 175-188Google Scholar). To investigate their possible involvement in SgIII processing, CV-1 cells were cotransfected with SgIII and PC1 or PC2 cDNA constructs, pulse-labeled, and analyzed for the biosynthesis of SgIII. The incubation medium of cells cotransfected with SgIII and PC2 contained, in addition to the SgIII precursor forms, three smaller immunoreactive proteins whose sizes were indistinguishable from the SgIII-derived cleavage products generated in Xenopus NILs (Fig. 6, compare lanes 3 and 6). The same set of radiolabeled proteins could be immunoprecipitated from the incubation medium of cells cotransfected with SgIII and PC1 (Fig. 6, lane 8). The 20-kDa cleavage product generated in CV-1 cells often appeared as a smear in the gel (e.g. see Fig. 6, lane 7), hampering its detection in some of our experiments. This smearing, which was also evident for the 63-kDa precursor form, may relate to additional post-translational modifications of SgIII when produced in fibroblasts. Nevertheless, our results demonstrate that both PC1 and PC2 recognize SgIII as a suitable substrate. Unlike PC1, PC2 is a highly abundant protein in Xenopus melanotropes (13Holthuis J.C.M. Jansen E.J.R. Van Riel M.C.H.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Cell Sci. 1995; 108: 3295-3305Google Scholar, 30Braks J.A.M. Goldenmond K.C.W. Van Riel M.C.H.M. Coenen A.J.M. Martens G.J.M. FEBS Lett. 1994; 305: 45-50Google Scholar) and therefore represents the most likely enzyme to be responsible for the processing of SgIII in these cells. Xenopus SgIII contains seven potential dibasic cleavage sites (Fig. 1). As mentioned above, the first cleavage yielding the 48-kDa product is in the amino-terminal region of the protein, yet carboxyl-terminal of the N-linked glycosylation site (Asn47). We noticed that upon cleavage of the 48-kDa product, 2- to 3-times more radioactivity remains associated with the 28-kDa fragment than with the 20-kDa fragment (see Fig. 2 or 3). Combined with the distribution of methionines in the SgIII polypeptide sequence (Fig. 1), these observations led us to predict that the first cleavage of SgIII occurs at the Lys68-Arg69 site and the second cleavage at the Arg237-Arg238 site. To test this hypothesis, amino acid substitutions were introduced at these sites, and the mutated proteins were coexpressed with PC2 in CV-1 fibroblasts. The mutant in which the Lys68-Arg69 site was substituted by Thr68-Ser69 gave rise to the SgIII precursor forms and a single cleavage product of 28 kDa (Fig. 7, lane 3). Other potential SgIII fragments were undetectable, even in overexposed gels. When the Arg237-Arg238 site was substituted by Ser237-Ser238, only one cleavage product of 48 kDa was detected (Fig. 7, lane 4). The intact precursors but no cleavage products were observed after expressing the mutant that carried substitutions at both sites (Fig. 7, lane 5). Together, these results confirm our prediction that the endoproteolytic conversion of SgIII in Xenopus melanotropes results from cleavages at Lys68-Arg69 and Arg237-Arg238. For example, rodent SgIII lacks the functional Lys68-Arg69 cleavage site found in the Xenopus protein (14Holthuis J.C.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Neurochem. 1996; (in press)Google Scholar). The identification of a bovine chromaffin granule-associated peptide corresponding to the region amino-terminal of the dibasic Arg95-Lys96 in rodent SgIII (31Sigafoos J. Chestnut W.G. Merrill B.M. Taylor L.C.E. Diliberto Jr., E.J. Viveros O.H. J. Anat. 1993; 183: 253-264Google Scholar), a pair not present in the Xenopus protein, further substantiates the notion that SgIII processing in the various species involves dibasic sites that are not conserved during vertebrate evolution. Ottiger et al. (11Ottiger H.-P. Battenberg E.F. Tsou A.P. Bloom F.E. Sutcliffe J.G. J. Neurosci. 1990; 10: 3135-3147Google Scholar) previously reported on a single SgIII protein of ∼57 kDa which was detected by Western blot analysis in various regions of the rat brain. We did not observe a newly synthesized SgIII-related protein of this size in rat pituitary or mouse endocrine cells. In view of the present data, the possibility should be considered that the protein detected by Ottiger and co-workers (11Ottiger H.-P. Battenberg E.F. Tsou A.P. Bloom F.E. Sutcliffe J.G. J. Neurosci. 1990; 10: 3135-3147Google Scholar) does not represent intact SgIII but is a SgIII-derived cleavage product. In this study, we have shown that SgIII is a sulfated precursor protein whose endoproteolytic processing is a wide-spread phenomenon in the neuroendocrine system of vertebrates. At present, the significance of SgIII processing is unclear. The possibility that it serves to liberate functionally important peptides, conforming to what has been proposed for CgA and SgII (3Galindo E. Rill A. Bader M.F. Aunis D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 1426-1430Google Scholar, 4Tatemoto K. Efendic S. Mutt V. Makk G. Feistner G.J. Barchar J.D. Nature. 1986; 324: 476-478Google Scholar, 5Saria A. Troger J. Kirchmair R. Fischer-Colbrie R. Hogue-Angeletti R. Winkler H. Neuroscience. 1993; 54: 1-4Google Scholar), is unlikely. First, the majority of potential dibasic cleavage sites in SgIII is not conserved during vertebrate evolution (14Holthuis J.C.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Neurochem. 1996; (in press)Google Scholar). Moreover, our present data demonstrate that Xenopus SgIII is fully processed at the nonconserved Lys68-Arg69 site, whereas only partial cleavage occurs at the conserved Arg237-Arg238 site (as diagrammed in Fig. 8). Therefore, if SgIII belongs to the group of prohormones and neuropeptide precursors, it would represent a notable exception since the members of this class are generally cleaved at conserved dibasic sites (32Martens G.J.M. Civelli O. Herbert E. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 13685-13689Google Scholar). Second, a comparative analysis of SgIII protein sequences from Xenopus and rodents showed that regions with the highest degree of sequence identity (over 90%) are not flanked by dibasic sites (14Holthuis J.C.M. Martens G.J.M. J. Neurochem. 1996; (in press)Google Scholar), in contrast to what one would expect for a genuine peptide precursor. In fact, the two functional cleavage sites in Xenopus SgIII each reside within a poorly conserved region where the degree of sequence identity has dropped below 30%. If not to liberate bioactive peptides, what then is the purpose of SgIII processing? It may terminate a function exerted by the intact protein in the early secretory compartments. An interesting example in this respect concerns the neuroendocrine protein 7B2 (SgV). When travelling through the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi compartments, the uncleaved form of 7B2 is associated with and appears to prevent premature activation of pro-PC2 (7Martens G.J.M. Braks J.A.M. Eib D.W. Zhou Y. Lindberg I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5784-5787Google Scholar, 8Braks J.A.M. Martens G.J.M. Cell. 1994; 78: 263-273Google Scholar, 10Benjannet S. Savaria D. Chrétien M. Seidah N.G. J. Neurochem. 1995; 64: 2303-2311Google Scholar). Upon arrival in the TGN, 7B2 is cleaved and dissociates from pro-PC2, allowing the proenzyme to mature. Given the existence of a private chaperone for PC2, it is conceivable that additional helper proteins interact with other enzymes in the secretory pathway. If SgIII represents such a helper protein, then its processing could trigger complex dissociation. Another possibility is that SgIII promotes the selective aggregation of luminal proteins and their subsequent packaging into secretory granules, whereby its processing serves to dissolve and/or facilitate maturation of the granular content. Alternatively, the proteolytic conversion of SgIII may simply reflect the fate of the protein in the regulated secretory pathway rather than being essential for its mechanism of action. The function of SgIII remains to be established. Neither the genetic ablation of its gene in mice (12Kingsley D.M. Rinchick E.M. Russell L.B. Ottiger H.-P. Sutcliffe J.G. Copeland N.G. Jenkins N.A. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 395-399Google Scholar) nor its overexpression in cultured neuroendocrine cells2 has provided any clue with respect to the role of this protein in the neuroendocrine system. The results of our present study show that SgIII itself is a precursor molecule and can only have an intracellular function, whereas an extracellular role can only be attributed to SgIII-derived peptides. We are grateful to K. Janssen and Y. Croes for technical assistance, R. Engels for animal care, and D. Eib and M. van Horssen for critically reading the manuscript.

In this study, the effects of high levels of guanosine tetraphosphate (ppGpp) on the decay and RNA chain elongation kinetics of the bacteriophage λ late transcript in Escherichia coli were examined in the absence of amino acid starvation. The accumulation, mRNA decay kinetics, and RNA chain elongation rate of the λ late mRNA were determined after heat induction of λcI857 lysogens in the presence of high levels of ppGpp induced from a RelAα fragment-overproducing plasmid. The accumulation kinetics and elongation rate determinations of the late mRNA were made at long times after induction to allow a new steady state of transcriptional activities under conditions of elevated intracellular levels of ppGpp. The results indicate no prolonged or significant effect on either mRNA decay or the RNA chain elongation rate of the late mRNA as a result of elevated ppGpp levels. Surprisingly, the RNA chain elongation rate determinations indicate an RNA polymerase processivity of approximately 90-100 nucleotides/s for the λ late transcript despite the presence of high levels of ppGpp. The results are discussed in terms of various models for regulation of stable and messenger RNA synthesis in E. coli. Apoptotic cell death has been correlated to DNA fragmentation into discrete segments corresponding to the length of nucleosomal protected fragments of 180–200 base pairs or multiples of it. This DNA degradation has been ascribed to endonuclease activity that cleaves internucleosomally, thus giving rise to a ladder distribution upon electrophoretic migration. This strict correlation was, however, shown to have notable exceptions, since in some cases only single strand cleavage in the internucleosomal DNA regions has been observed (Tomei, D. L., Shapiro, P. J., and Cope, O. F. (1993) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 90, 853–857). In the present work we show that mouse muscle cells, able to differentiate in vitro, if subjected to apoptosis present no DNA degradation into ladder form unless differentiation is previously induced. Furthermore, C3H/10T1/2 fibroblast cells, known to undergo apoptosis without DNA ladder formation, if converted to a myogenic program by MyoD expression, display internucleosomal DNA degradation upon induction of differentiation. In the present work we show that mouse muscle cells, able to differentiate in vitro, if subjected to apoptosis present no DNA degradation into ladder form unless differentiation is previously induced. Furthermore, C3H/10T1/2 fibroblast cells, known to undergo apoptosis without DNA ladder formation, if converted to a myogenic program by MyoD expression, display internucleosomal DNA degradation upon induction of differentiation. A set of biochemical and morphological features characterizes the process of cell death by apoptosis (1Martin J.S. Douglas R.G. Cotter G.T. Trends Biol. Sci. 1994; 19: 26-28Google Scholar). This phenomenon, associated with several developmental processes and tissue homeostasis, is often called programmed cell death to indicate a physiological, naturally occurring cell death (2Kerr J.F.R. Wyllie A.H. Currie A.R. Br. J. Cancer. 1972; 26: 239-257Google Scholar, 3Wyllie A.H. Kerr J.F.R. Currie A.R. Int. Rev. Cytol. 1980; 68: 251-306Google Scholar). In addition to physiological stimuli, apoptosis can also be induced both in vivo and in vitro by a variety of cytotoxic drugs and physical stimuli (4Barry M.A. Behnke C.A. Eastman A. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1990; 40: 2352-2362Google Scholar, 5Bertrand R. Kerrigan D. Saragan M. Pommier Y. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1991; 42: 77-85Google Scholar, 6Chow S.C. Peters I. Orrenius S. Exp. Cell Res. 1995; 216: 149-159Google Scholar) and is characterized by some typical parameters such as cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, nuclear apoptotic bodies, and DNA degradation that clearly differentiate this cell death from necrosis (for reviews on apoptosis and programmed cell death see 1Martin J.S. Douglas R.G. Cotter G.T. Trends Biol. Sci. 1994; 19: 26-28Google Scholar and 7Ellis R.E. Yuan J. Horvitz H.R. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1991; 7: 663-698Google Scholar, 8Vaux L.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 786-789Google Scholar, 9Bortner D.C. Oldenburg B.E.N. Cidlowski A.J. Trends Biol. Sci. 1995; 5: 21-26Google Scholar). For many years it was thought that the strictest marker of apoptosis was the DNA degradation in fragments of oligonucleosomal size (multiples of approximately 180 base pairs). This fragmentation is easily evidenced by the electrophoretic migration of DNA into a ladder configuration. Although internucleosomal DNA degradation has long been considered the cause of chromatin morphological alterations, in the last years many investigators have observed apoptotic phenotypes in the absence of ladder formation. In these cases, however, other types of DNA modification have been observed, such as single strand breaks (10Tomei D.L. Shapiro P.J. Cope O.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 853-857Google Scholar) or cleavage into large DNA fragments of 50–300 kilobase pairs (11Oberhammer F. Wilson W.T. Dive C. Morris D.I. Wakeling E.A. Walker P.R. Sikorska M. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 3679-3684Google Scholar) (see also Table 1 in 9Bortner D.C. Oldenburg B.E.N. Cidlowski A.J. Trends Biol. Sci. 1995; 5: 21-26Google Scholar). Evidence now suggests that DNA degradation could be a late, dispensable step in the apoptotic process, perhaps important in vivo for a safe elimination of apoptotic cells by the organism (12Brown D.G. Sun X.M. Cohen G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 3037-3039Google Scholar, 13Oberhammer F. Bursch W. Tiefenbacher R. Froschl G. Pavelka M. Purchio T. Schulte-Hermann R. Hepatology. 1993; 18: 1238-1246Google Scholar, 14Cohen G.M. Sun X.M. Snowden R.T. Dinsdale D. Skilleter D.N. Biochem. J. 1992; 286: 331-334Google Scholar). Several nucleases have been invoked as responsible for apoptotic DNA degradation (15Peitsch M.C. Polzar B. Tschopp J. Mannherz H.G. Cell Death & Differ. 1994; 1: 1-6Google Scholar, 16Eastman A. Cell Death & Differ. 1994; 1: 7-9Google Scholar, 17Hughes Jr., F.M. Cidlowski A.J. Cell Death & Differ. 1994; 1: 11-17Google Scholar), but their involvement in this process is supported only by indirect evidence. It is not clear yet whether it is always the same or there are different nucleases that participate in DNA fragmentation in different cell systems and in different apoptosis inducing conditions or whether this enzymatic activity results from the activation of a preexisting nuclease or from its de novo synthesis. Our present results deal with the observation that apoptosis in myoblast cells displays different degradation patterns correlated with the degree of cell differentiation. The possibility to modulate the pattern of apoptosis renders this cell system useful for the investigation of the pathways leading to DNA fragmentation.
